review.title: Lifted Message Passing for the Generalized Belief Propagation
review.abstract: We introduce the lifted Generalized Belief Propagation (GBP) message passing algorithm, for the computation of sum-product queries in Probabilistic Relational Models (e.g. Markov logic network). The algorithm forms a compact region graph and establishes a modified version of message passing, which mimics the GBP behavior in a corresponding ground model. The compact graph is obtained by exploiting a graphical representation of clusters, which reduces cluster symmetry detection to isomorphism tests on small local graphs. The framework is thus capable of handling complex models, while remaining domain-size independent.

metadata.title: Lifted Message Passing for the Generalized Belief Propagation

sections.text: ar Xiv: 161 0.01 525v 1 [cs.A I] 5 OFor the calculation of sum product queries in probabilistic relational models (e.g. Markov logic network), we introduce the Generalized Belief Propagation (GBP) algorithm. The algorithm forms a compact regional graph and establishes a modified version of message transmission that mimics the GBP behavior in a corresponding ground model. A compact graph is obtained by utilizing a graphical representation of clusters that reduces cluster symmetry recognition to isomorphic tests on small local graphs. Thus, the framework is able to handle complex models while remaining independent of domain size.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Probabilistic Relational Models (PRM) (e.g. Markov Logic Network [13]) are compact and expressive representations of probability models that concisely capture probability calculation using the language of predicate logic. Nevertheless, their compactness is a challenging task that has led to a family of algorithms focused on exploiting inherent symmetry. One of the most popular methods is the adaptation of the famous sum product Belief Propagation (BP).

sections.heading: 2 Background
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 Inference in Markov Random Field (MRF)
sections.text: A Markov Random Field (MRF) M is a probabilistic graphical model consisting of a series of random variables x = {xi} i and a series of factors. A factor is a pair (φf, xf) representing a function φf: range (xf) → R +, which is mapped from the common allocation range of variables xf x to the non-negative reals. The common distribution function of MRFs is given by Pr (x = x) = 1Z-f φf (x-f) (1), where x-f is a common allocation to all x variables, x-f is the respective common allocation to all xf variables under x, and Z stands for a normalization constant called the partition function. A common task in MRFs is that of marginalization, where the probability of all possible states in a subset of variables x'x is calculated as follows.

sections.heading: 2.2 Generalized Belief Propagation (GBP)
sections.text: One such approach method is the summary product of faith multiplication (BP). The algorithm plans messages between adjacent nodes in the graphical models until the messages converge, thereby simultaneously calculating margins for all random variables in the model. Although BP does not guarantee to be able to converge in diagrams that contain loops, the method often comes to a reasonable set of approximations to the correct boundary distributions [7]. The result then corresponds to a stationary point of approximation to the free energy of Bethe. The Generalized Belief Propagation (GBP) algorithm is, as its name suggests, a generalization of the BP algorithm. GBP messages are sent from one cluster of variables to another, in a graphical structure called a regional diagram. When the algorithm converges, the result corresponds to a stationary point of the GBP message, compared with the free approximation of the energy of Kikchi to the child.

sections.heading: 2.2.1 Regions and Region Graphs
sections.text: A region [20] is a tuple (xα, fα) representing a node in the GBP message. xα is a cluster of MRF variables with a corresponding set of indexes α, and fα is a set of MRF factors whose scope is a subset of xα (or xα complete). For simplicity's sake, we assume that fα contains all factors within the framework of xα. Therefore, the notation α will be sufficient to denote a region with a corresponding range of variables. (1) A regional graph GR = (V, E) is a direct acyclic graph, where nodes in V denote regions and directed edges in E parent-child-child (source-target) relationships. We define the conditions that a regional graph must respect as follows. (1) For each pair of different regions α1, α2, which are not subsets of each other, there is an intersection β = 1.

sections.heading: 2.2.2 Parent-To-Child Message Passing
sections.text: The algorithm begins with the arbitrary definition of messages mα → β from all parent regions to their child regions. At each stage of the algorithm, the messages are updated according to the following rules: bα (xα); f); f (xf); f); f); f); f); f); f); f); f); f); f); f); f); f); f); f); f; f (xf); f); f); f); f; f; f); f); f); f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f; f

sections.heading: 3 Probabilistic Relational Models
sections.text: Probabilistic Relational Models (PRM) are representations of probability models that use the language of predicate logic of the first order. Of the two most common models, the Markov logic network [13] and the parfactor model [12], we choose the latter to represent a relational MRF. Therefore, we include a brief introduction to the parameter model and refer to [5] for a more comprehensive overview.

sections.heading: 3.1 Relational MRF
sections.text: A domain is a series of constants, so-called domain objects, which represent different units in the modeled world. An atom is an atomic formula of the form p (t1,.., tn), in which the symbol is referred to as predicate1, and each term ti is either a domain object or an lvar. An earth atom is an atom whose ti terms are all domain objects. Non-earth atoms are aggregations of earth atoms, which all have the same mapping range and describe a certain property of an individual (e.g. smoker) or a relationship between individuals (e.g. friendship). An earth atom is an atom whose ti terms are all domain objects. Non-earth atoms are aggregations of earth atoms, which all have the same mapping range and describe a certain property of an individual (e.g. friendship). A soil substitution {Xi / oi} i, is the replacement of each lvar model of a parameter called a domain factor.The MRi is a collection of parameters.

sections.heading: 3.2 Symmetry Between Clusters
sections.text: The representation of first order relational models introduces a considerable degree of symmetry, which can be used for either exact or approximate inference. In exact conclusion, computational operators typically have to take into account the division of the model into isomorphic components [17]. In comparison, approximate inference methods [11, 3, 10] are able to use a more relaxed form of symmetry shown between clusters of MRF variables. [1] Although the term predicate is used, atoms are not limited to boolean assignments. Definition 1 cluster xα and xα ′ are considered symmetric if a structure exists that preserves permutation on the variables of the MRF (i.e. a permutation belonging to the automorphism group of the graphic model), under which each xi-xα is mapped to a distinctive xj-xα structure.

sections.heading: 3.2.1 Cluster Signatures and Canonical Clusters
sections.text: Let xα denote a cluster of ground atoms obtained from the relational MRF Mr. The Cluster Signature Graph (CSG) of xα, the projection of its contents on a graph, in a way that guarantees two important properties: (i) If the CSGs of xα and xα ′ are isomorphic, then xα and xα ′ are symmetrical. (ii) The mapping induced by such isomorphism represents a structural permutation in the relational MRF. Due to lack of space, we present a simpler definition of CSG than that of [2], which covers slightly less symmetry and refers to fragmented models. Definition 2 The CSG of cluster xα is a directed colored multigraph G = (V, E, C), where V is a series of clusters, E is a set of directed edges, and C is a color function.

sections.heading: 4 Lifting the Generalized Belief Propagation
sections.text: The repeal of universal belief can be considered a two-step process. First, a compact regional graph is formed in the face of a relational MRF and a number of outer regions, consisting entirely of regions corresponding to canonical clusters. Second, an algorithm for message delivery is used that is specially adapted to the raised graph and produces exactly the same result as the ground GBP. We begin with a brief overview of the raised framework.

sections.heading: 4.1 Lifted GBP – An Overview
sections.text: Imagine a regional graph for the relational MRF φ (p (X), q (Y) β | X 6 = Y), where all pairs {pi, qj} (i 6 = j) serve as outer regions. Such a graph can be achieved by finding all intersections induced by the {pi, qj} pairs, and defining two edges from each pair to its members: {pi, qj} and {pi, qj} → qj. However, the highly symmetrical character of the regional graph allows to grasp its structure much more precisely, via a representation that simulates the description given above. First, we define symmetry in the context of the regional graphs. Regions α and α ′ will be symmetrical if there is a permutation. R on the regional graph there are nodes that preserve its structure, and under which ratios R (α) symmetry of the relative regions is derived directly.

sections.heading: 4.2 Symmetry-Preserving Properties
sections.text: The superseded GBP framework is based on two symmetrically oriented properties. The first is that symmetry-preserving permutations for the regional graph are derived from the common structure of the MRF and the group of selected outer regions. The second property formalizes the symmetry that preserves the nature of the flood plan and allows a compact representation of the flow of messages. Formally, Theorem 1 Let it designate a series of outer regions for MRF M. and let GR designate a regional graph obtained by iterative intersections. Then, any permutation of M's variables that preserves the structure of both B and M causes a permutation of R that, when applied to the regional graph's nodes, preserves its structure. Theorem 2 Let G designate a graph, and let π R be a structure that preserves permutation on the nodes of the graph.

sections.heading: 4.3 Generating the Lifted Region Graph
sections.text: Before generating the graph, we must choose which outer regions represent the represented regions. A natural pick would be all regions with a circumference corresponding to the factors in the soil. The added value of this pick is that, if carefully constructed, each soil instance of a perffactor corresponds to a circumference of any canonical cluster. Specifically, if an X! = Y constraint is injected for each pair of lvars X, Y in the model, and the model is disrupted accordingly, the canonical outer regions can be selected without any computational effort. We continue with a formal definition of the raised region. Definition 3 A raised Regional Graph GR = (V, E, N) is a direct cyclic multigraph with nodes in V denoted regions, oriented edges in E denoted regions parents to child relationships associating any function that associates each edge with an image of the child to those of the parents.

sections.heading: 4.4 Computing the Parent-Child Cardinality
sections.text: The cardinality of the edge is the number of all clusters in the relational MRF that are mapped to xα in a structure that maintains the permutation, while all members of the edge are mapped to themselves. Thus, in models with objects of the N domain, where nβ2We indicate that the procedure under this chosen formulation can produce an upscale regional graph consisting of non-intersecting areas that serve only as targets for a single directed edge and whose cardinality is equal to 1. Alternatively, such regions can be removed from the graph by connecting their parents directly to their children. It is the number of objects referenced in the cluster xβ, and nα\ β is the number of domain objects in xβ that are not referenced by xβ, the cardinality is the number of objects that are referenced in the cluster xβ.

sections.heading: 4.5 Lifted Message Passing
sections.text: The key to the formation of the messages is that the different descendants of a region (e.g. region), although they may be members of the same symmetry class, may not be derived from one to the other. Each belief is derived from the structure of the graph raised and the internal structure of the region. The reason for this mixture is that the different descendants of a region (e.g. region), although they may be members of the same symmetry class, may not be attributable to the other. To overcome this obstacle, we define the concept of a local graph that cancels the maps on itself. Subsets of the graph raised that are symmetrical w.r.t. The global structure can still influence the state of belief in a non-symmetrical state. To overcome this obstacle, we define the concept of a local graph of the canonical region.

sections.heading: 5 Empirical Evaluation
sections.text: We conducted experiments with 4 structurally distinctive relationship models: the first model is a friend-smoker model (i.e. friends (X, Y), smokers (X) = smokers (Y), the second is a transitive model [2], the third is a transitive friend-white model [1], and the fourth is the chain model whose regional diagrams are shown in Figure 1. Graphic isomorphism tests were performed with the NetworkX package [6]. The time required to create the upscale diagrams was found to be in the range of tens of milliseconds. In all experiments, we performed 500 iterations of uplifted GBP messages, which were performed with a damping factor of 0.5 and the normalization of both beliefs and messages. Messages were performed in the protocol room to maintain numerical stability. Time performance and query results were normalized with the WFOMC [CBP] motor [querified for the position of the GBP], as well as the GBP [queried for the position of the GBP] were not calculated.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: Although the scope of this work is limited to summary product queries, the compact formulation of the upscale regional graph can serve other algorithms based on a similar structure. An aspect worth investigating is the extension of the scope of outer regions, not only to first-order regions, but also to all regions of a given size, similar to lifting and project hierarchies [15]. Such experiments can lead to streamlined results and improved convergence in highly complex models.

referenceMentions.context: Markov logic network [13]) are compact and expressive representations of probabilistic models, which succinctly capture probabilistic rules using the language of first-order predicate logic.
One of the popular lifted inference methods is an adaptation of the famous sum-product Belief-Propagation (BP) [21] algorithm to relational models [8, 16].
One of the popular lifted inference methods is an adaptation of the famous sum-product Belief-Propagation (BP) [21] algorithm to relational models [8, 16].
One of the popular lifted inference methods is an adaptation of the famous sum-product Belief-Propagation (BP) [21] algorithm to relational models [8, 16].

In this paper we introduce the first domain-size independent framework which lifts the generalized BP algorithm (GBP) [21] in its classical message passing form, and thus allows the injection of more constraints on the marginals compared with non-generalized BP implementations.

A related work by [18] introduced a method which produces similar approximations, by relaxing the relational model’s structure [4], compensating for the relaxation and finally performing exact inference.

A related work by [18] introduced a method which produces similar approximations, by relaxing the relational model’s structure [4], compensating for the relaxation and finally performing exact inference.

Our work heavily relies on a recently introduced graphical platform called Cluster Signature Graph (CSG) [2], which projects the relational structure of clusters of variables onto a graph, and allows symmetry detection via an isomorphism test.
The marginalization task is #P-complete [14], and it is therefore common to approximate its result, rather than to carry out exact computations.
Although BP does not guarantee to converge in graphs that contain loops, the procedure often arrives at a reasonable set of approximations to the correct marginal distributions [7].
When the algorithm converges, the result corresponds to a stationary point of the Kikuchi free energy approximation [21], a tighter free energy approximation compared with Bethe.
A region [20] is a tuple (xα, fα), which represents a node in the GBP message passing graph.

Generating region graphs can be understood as an iterative process [21], where region intersections are applied, first on outer regions, which are given as input, and then on the resulting intersections.
Of the two most common models, Markov logic network [13] and the parfactor model [12], we choose the latter to represent a relational MRF.

We restrict our attention to shattered [5] models, consisting of inequality constraints of the form X 6= Y only.

In comparison, approximate inference methods [11, 3, 10] are able to exploit a more relaxed form of symmetry, one that is exhibited between clusters of MRF variables.

In [2], a platform based on graphical signatures of clusters is introduced, providing a principled way to incorporate clustering based methods in lifted inference.

Graph isomorphism tests were conducted using the NetworkX package [6].
Time performance and query results were compared against the WFOMC [19] engine, which is capable of computing GBP queries (Lifted RCR), as well as lifted BP (LBP).

One aspect worth exploring is extending the scope of outer regions, not only to regions defined using first-order theory, but also to all regions of a given size, similarly to lift and project hierarchies [15].

metadata.abstractText: We introduce the lifted Generalized Belief Propagation (GBP) message passing algorithm, for the computation of sum-product queries in Probabilistic Relational Models (e.g. Markov logic network). The algorithm forms a compact region graph and establishes a modified version of message passing, which mimics the GBP behavior in a corresponding ground model. The compact graph is obtained by exploiting a graphical representation of clusters, which reduces cluster symmetry detection to isomorphism tests on small local graphs. The framework is thus capable of handling complex models, while remaining domain-size independent.
